key_points: Michigan school district announces zero tolerance policy toward threats and other safety initiatives after a school shooting.
The changes were announced two weeks after the Nov. 30 shooting at Oxford High School that left four students dead and seven others wounded.
Ethan Crumbley, a 15-year-old student, has been charged with murder and other crimes related to the shooting.
Ethan Crumbley's parents are charged with involuntary manslaughter for allegedly giving their son access to a gun and failing to intervene despite concerning signs.
School safety measures include law enforcement presence in all schools, hiring a security firm for additional guards, and prohibiting backpacks.
Criticism has been aimed at school officials for not taking preemptive action, despite signs of potential danger.
Public concerns were raised at a board meeting about the existing policies and response to the warning signs before the shooting.
The community and students are experiencing trauma and fear for their safety in the aftermath of the shooting.
Court proceedings for Ethan Crumbley and his parents have been delayed to give the Michigan community time to heal and prepare.
Oxford High School has been closed since the incident, with other schools also temporarily closed due to online threats.
spokespersons: Jill Lemond (Assistant Superintendent of Student Services)
Lori Bourgeau (Oxford Village Councilwoman and Parent)
